questions.text: A patient presents with a fever and a red, tender, swollen left knee, which started two days ago. He was recently diagnosed with hypertension and started on hydrochlorothiazide. Immediate joint aspiration is done, and the microscopic picture is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B)¬†Naproxen

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario and microscopy showing negatively birefringent urate crystals suggest acute gouty arthritis, and naproxen is the most appropriate initial drug for this patient.

  • Gout is a metabolic disorder characterized by hyperuricemia (normal plasma urate 2-6mg/dl).
  • Secondary hyperuricemia can be caused by diseases like leukemias, lymphomas, polycythemias; or drugs like thiazides, furosemide, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, levodopa, that reduce the uric acid excretion by kidney.¬†
  • Acute gouty arthritis:
    • It is a sudden onset of severe inflammation in a small joint (M/C: metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe) due to precipitation of urate crystals in the joint space.
    • The joint becomes red, swollen, and extremely painful, requiring immediate treatment.
    • Management:
      • First-line: NSAIDs (all except aspirin and paracetamol).
        • E.g. Naproxen, piroxicam, diclofenac, indomethacin, or etoricoxib.
      • NSAID resistant cases: Colchicine.
      • Colchicine resistant cases: Intra-articular corticosteroids.

¬†

¬†

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of chronic hyperuricemia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)¬†Etoricoxib

Explanation:

Etoricoxib, which is an NSAID, will not be used in chronic hyperuricemia/chronic gout. Instead, it can be used to treat acute gout attacks.

Chronic gout:

  • Persistence of pain and stiffness in joints in between the attacks.
  • Other cardinal features are hyperuricemia, tophi, and urate stones in the kidney.
  • In most cases, hyperuricemia is due to the under-secretion of uric acid, while in a few, it is due to overproduction.
  • Chronic gouty arthritis may cause progressive deformities and permanent disabilities.
  • Drugs used in chronic gout:
    • Uricosurics:
      • They increase uric acid excretion.
      • Drugs: Probenecid, sulfinpyrazone, lesinurad, benzbromarone.
    • Uric acid synthesis inhibitors:
      • They inhibit xanthine oxidase, inhibiting uric acid synthesis.¬†(Options B & c ruled out)
      • Allopurinol, febuxostat.¬†(Option D ruled out)

¬†

¬†

questions.text: A patient complains of persistent pain and stiffness over both his big toes and right knee over the past 2 years. X-ray of big toe showed deposition of uric acid crystals. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug of choice to reduce uric acid levels?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B)¬†Allopurinol

Explanation:

The given clinical scenario, along with the x-ray findings of the big toe, showing deposition of uric acid crystals,¬†is suggestive of chronic gout and allopurinol is the most appropriate drug of choice among the given options.¬†Rat bite erosions, also known as¬†Martel sign¬†or¬†G sign, are seen in gout¬†and refer to punched out erosions with sclerotic and overhanging margins.

Allopurinol:

  • Allopurinol was initially synthesized as an antineoplastic agent, but was later found to lack anti-cancer property, but an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase (XO).
  • Both allopurinol and its primary metabolite, oxypurinol (alloxanthine), reduce urate production by inhibiting XO, the enzyme that converts xanthine to uric acid.
  • Allopurinol competitively inhibits XO at low concentrations and is a non-competitive inhibitor at high concentrations.
  • It is the drug of choice for treatment of chronic gout, however there is a risk of acute attack in the beginning due to compensatory mobilisation of tissue stores into plasma.
  • Hence, colchicine or NSAIDs are given along with in the beginning.
  • Other uses of allopurinol:
    • Tumour lysis syndrome.
    • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
    • Post-transplant patients.

Piroxicam, Etoricoxib (NSAIDS) and Hydrocortisone (steroids), are used in the management of acute gout attacks. (Options A, C and D ruled out)

¬†

¬†

questions.text: All of the following about allopurinol are incorrect except?

choices.text: Allopurinol is largely bound to plasma proteins.
Allopurinol reduces the activity of azathioprine.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D)¬†Allopurinol is contraindicated during lactation.

Explanation:

Pharmacokinetics of allopurinol:

  • Allopurinol (half-life of 2 hours) is shorter acting than its metabolite alloxanthine (half-life of 24 hours). (Option A)
  • 80% of orally administered allopurinol is absorbed orally; it is not bound to plasma proteins and is metabolised to xanthine (Option B).
  • Drug interactions:
    • Allopurinol inhibits the degradation of 6-mercaptopurine and azathioprine, increasing their concentrations (Option C).
    • Probenecid + allopurinol:
      • Probenecid shortens the t1/2 of allopurinol.
      • Allopurinol prolongs the t1/2 of probenecid.
    • Allopurinol can potentiate warfarin and theophylline by inhibiting their metabolism.
    • Allopurinol + ampicillin: Higher incidence of skin rashes.
  • Contraindications: Hypersensitivity, pregnancy, and lactation (Option D).
  • Cautious use is recommended in
    • Extremes of age.
    • Patients with kidney and liver disease.

¬†

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of chronic gout presented with recurrent episodes of painful attacks despite being on allopurinol. His physician suggests a drug that inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubules. Which of the following drugs uses this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)¬†Probenicid

Explanation:

  • Probenecid inhibits the URAT1 transporter in the proximal convoluted tubule, thereby reducing reabsorption of uric acid and increasing its excretion.
    ¬†
  • It is classified as a uricosuric agent, effective in patients who under-excrete uric acid.
    ¬†
  • It is useful in chronic gout, particularly when allopurinol or febuxostat alone is insufficient.
    ¬†

¬†

Febuxostat (Option B): Incorrect because it inhibits xanthine oxidase, not uric acid reabsorption.
¬†

Rasburicase (Option C): Incorrect because it converts uric acid to allantoin, used in tumor lysis syndrome, not chronic gout.
¬†

Colchicine (Option D): Incorrect because it acts by inhibiting neutrophil chemotaxis and is used for acute gout, not for reducing uric acid levels chronically.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of gout presents to the clinic with increased frequency of gout attacks. His daily medications include rosuvastatin, low-dose aspirin and losartan for hypertension. He has been advised to avoid certain medications that can exacerbate his gout. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Aspirin affects renal handling of uric acid in two ways:

  • High doses (>3 g/day): Uricosuric effect (blocking urate reabsorption).
  • Low doses (<2 g/day): Uric acid retention (inhibiting urate secretion).

Gout triggers can include alcohol, red meat and certain medications.¬†

Drugs Associated with Gout

Drugs causing gout

Drugs beneficial in gout

  • A: Aspirin (Normal dose <2 gms)
  • I: Immunosuppressive: Cyclosporine
  • N: Niacin
  • E: Ethambutol
  • D: Diuretic like loop diuretics, thiazides

Mnemonic ‚Äì FALSe

  • F: Fenofibrate

Treatment for drug-induced gout: Continue the drug + Allopurinol.

Note: Allopurinol (Option A) benefits gout by reducing uric acid production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with a 3-year history of worsening joint pain presented to the clinic with early morning stiffness and swelling in her wrists. Her symptoms were not relieved with ibuprofen. A physical examination of the hands is shown. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer:¬†C)¬†Methotrexate

Explanation:

Methotrexate should be used as the first line of treatment for this adult female patient with chronic pain with early morning stiffness and swelling in her wrist joints, as well as hand deformity (swan-neck and boutonni√®rere deformity) in the image.

Methotrexate (Anchor drug):

  • Dose: Low dose (10-25 mg/week).
  • Uses: Most effective drug for RA.
  • Onset: action starts > 1 month.
  • Contraindications: Pregnancy (neural tube defects) and lactation.
  • Toxicity antidote: Folinic acid/ Leucovorin.
  • Methotrexate resistance: Use anti-TNF-alpha or CD20 inhibitor.

¬†

  • Hydroxychloroquine and Sulfasalazine are used in RA but are generally considered less effective than methotrexate for moderate to severe cases. (Options¬†A and B ruled out)

¬†

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient with a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for 5 years presents to the clinic with complaints of nausea, fatigue, mouth ulcers and an unusual rash on her legs. She has been on a stable regimen of DMARDs for the past few years. Laboratory investigations reveal a decreased Hb level, elevated liver enzymes, and mild leukopenia. Which drug is most likely responsible for her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct answer:¬†C)¬†Methotrexate

Explanation:

A patient with a known case of rheumatoid arthritis on DMARDs presenting with nausea, fatigue, mouth ulcers, rash on her legs, and labs showing anaemia, elevated liver enzymes, and mild leukopenia suggests methotrexate use. It is the first-line drug used for patients with chronic rheumatoid arthritis.

Side effects of methotrexate:

  • Nausea, vomiting, and fatigue.
  • Oral ulcers.
  • Hair loss.
  • Hematologic:
    • Myelosuppression (decreased white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets).
  • Hepatic:
    • Elevated liver enzymes.
    • Hepatotoxicity.
  • Gastrointestinal:
    • Stomatitis (inflammation of the mouth).
    • Diarrhoea.
  • Other:
    • Skin rashes.
    • Increased incidence of chest infection.

Side effects of¬†Hydroxychloroquine.(Option A):

  • Gastrointestinal upset.
  • Skin rash.
  • Retinal toxicity.
  • Corneal opacity.

Side effects of Sulfasalazine¬†(Option B):

  • Gastrointestinal upset.
  • Rash.
  • Liver enzyme abnormalities.
  • Myelosuppression.

The combination of nausea, oral ulcers, significant hepatotoxicity, and a decrease in white blood cell count is more characteristic of methotrexate.

Side effects of¬†Penicillamine¬†(Option D):

  • Diarrhoea.
  • Dermatitis.
  • Drug-induced lupus.
  • Nephrotoxicity.

¬†
